description: 1600s, probably of North Germanic origin and ultimately imitative.

Related to Swedish dialectal skvabbel (“a dispute, quarrel, gossip”), Norwegian dialectal skvabba (“to prattle”), German dialectal schwabbeln (“to babble, prattle”), Swedish dialectal skvappa (“to chide, scold”, literally “make a splash”).

examples: The children got into a squabble about who should ride in the front of the car.

verbs.description: squabble (third-person singular simple present squabbles, present participle squabbling, simple past and past participle squabbled)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To participate in a minor fight or argument; to quarrel.
examples: The brothers were always squabbling with each other.

entries.meaning: (transitive, printing) To disarrange, so that the letters or lines stand awry and require readjustment.
